A Fatal Operation.

A sad cans of death from misadventure occurred yesterday in the Attarin quarter of Alexandria. A Greek from Pyrgoe, Angeles loglemi by name, was suffering from a severe attach of neuralgia. He called in a doctor to ease his agonies, and the latter injected morphia wi'h fatal results.

Native brokers in the Sudan are becoming as sharp as their brethren in Egypt. The other day a Khartoum broker sold some land registered in a notable a name without bia having been consulted about the transaction Not satisfied with the proceeds of the first sale the broker sold the same land again to another purchaser I

Tbs FlorioHubattinu S B. Umbria will ar rive at Alexandria on Sunday next, and will leave again on Thursday for Messina, Naples, Leghorn, and Genoa. Creak Assise Court

Yesterday au interesting sa e was tried before the Greek Areize Court at Alexandria It appears that a regular band if burglara and housebreakers conducted a campaign in Alex andria last summer. Several oases of burglary came to the notice of the police, and eventually two members uf the band, Antonio Mikhailo vioh and Garifaloe Ganfalou, ware arrested, but the rest of the gang have escaped Yesterday these two men were tried and sentenced to 92 and 24 mouths imprisonment respectively, the terms of imprisonment to run from the begin­ning if their incarceration,

The question of the imports of drink into Egypt has beeu intere-ding some members of the House rf Cemmons, and the following is the text of the questions that have been recent­ly asked : —

Dr. Rutherford (Middlesex, Brentford) 1 beg to ask the Secretary if State for Foreign Affairs whether he will procure from the Egyp tian Government, for the information of the House, a statement as to amounts and values of alcoholic liquors imported into Egypt during each of the years 1400 to 1906, showing the places of origin and destination and the natioa- alities of the consignors and consignee* , also a statement of the number of distilleries and breweries for the manufacture of alooholio liquors, showing in each case the towns and provinces in which they are situated, and the amounts and values of the outputs together with the nationalities if the proprietors for each of the years between 1900 and 1906.
Sir Edward Grey : I will make inquiry and get as much of the information ssked for as is obtainable.
EGYPTIAN BREWERIES AND
DISTILLERIES

Mr JM Robertson (Northumberland, Tyne side) 1 beg to ask the Under Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether in Egypt it is necessaiy that licences should be obtained for the opening and working of breweries and die tillerie*, and, if so, for what period such are granted; whether arrangements are in force for the inspection and supervision of such Iraweriesand diitillerie*, and for testing the quality and strength of the liquors produced, whether there is any law as to a copy of the same being produced for the information of the House, together with a statement as to the number of prosecutions, convictions, and repea’ed convictions of offending brewer* and distillers under such law, showing their nation alitiea ai d the penalties inflicted in each case during the years between 1900 and 1906.
Sir Edward Grey I will endeavour to obtain the information desired by the bon. Member.
RETAIL LIQUOR TRADE IN EGYPT

Mr J. M. Robertson . I beg to ask the Secre­tary of State fur Foreign Affairs whether he will procure for the information of the Hoose a copy of the licensing law relating to the retail sale of alcoholic liquor in Egypt, together with a statement a* to any modifications that may have been made therein, as to the present number of licensed and unlicens­ed retailers, and details of prosecutions and convictions of licensed and unlicensed re. tailers, and of persons charged with drunken nasi in connection with thore establishment*, in each of the year* te'w-ren 1900 and 1906 ; and whether the law, if any, relating to the adulteration of a'ooholic liquors in Egypt applies to, and is enforced against, retailers as well a< manufacturers.
Sir Edward Grey ; I will ask for as much of the information desired by the hon Member as ii obtainable

What is known generally at Alexandria as the • French Market," the property of the Alexandria Market C impany, Limited, has been brought by Hanan Pa>ha Mohsen and Mr. William Benwell Rees for £61,000 The area of the market is 3,580 square metre*, and it is situated in the heart ot the town The share­holders of the company will receive twenty pounds per » hare.

Whatever may have been done in other parts of Egypt for the wvlfare and happiness ot our guests during the 'X-na* holidays Helouan can at least take credit to itself for having provided most seasonable enjoyments for its visitors. Ths Grand Hote', besides providing a firstolaas dinner in all respects, commencing with turtle soup and finishing with good old English plum padding, had also a farther treat in store. One end of the large dining ball was illuminated by a beautiful 'Xmas Tree tastefully decorated and lighted with electric lamps of different colours. At the close of the dinner Dr. Hobson announced that the management had provided a further entertainment in the form of a tombola, or Italian lottery. Each guest bad a card given him containing certain numbers. Thsmaitre d’hfltel "Joseph then called out the numbers from the tombola. As soon as the possessor of a card had a complete row of five numbers as called out he then had the tight to select a prise from a table covered with a collsctioo of beautiful presents all nicely oonooalsd in appropriate wrappers. As there were over 100 priiM every guest had the privilege of present­ing a winning card and making his selection accordingly.

The collection of prizes was so numerous that space forbids our describing them all, but we must congratulate Mr. Manuel on receiving a most beautiful ladies' embroidered bolero. Lady Gilbert Parker was the early recipient of a beautiful prize. Rev, Campbell and Mr Fildes vied with one another in their race to be early at the tables, both receiving das rewards. Mrs Seligman and party were very successful in their drawings. The members sf Countess Karolyi’s family constantly appeared to be very del ghted with the amusement and were received with cheers whilst going to re caive their prizes. Altogether a most enjoyable evening was passed We bear that a grand ball will take place on the last day of the year, to see the new year in and the old year out.
ST MARK’S, ALEXANDRIA

The services on Christmas Day were largely attended, the numbers at the 7 30 a m. service being nearly double that of last year. At the 11am. service every seat wax occupied, including about 60 chairs which were placed in the aisle and at the west end ot the church. The choir sang the "Te Deum" to a setting by Rev E Vine Hall. The anthem was “Behold, I bring," by the same composer. Two offertory sentences were song and the first part of the service closed with the National Anthem. The Communion service was a simple setting by the Rev. F A. Gore Ouseley, though the time was by oo msans easy. The singing of the music was excellent, and did the choir credit. The two soprano solos in the anthem taken by Miss Callender, and the playing of the organ by Mr Heaton, were specially worthy of note.

The church and chapel were tastefully decor ated. Among those who sent offerings of flowers were Mrs. Batobeller, Mrs. Callender, Mire Coates, Mr J. E Cornish, Mrs. Crafton, Mrs. Dickson, Mr B W. P. Foster, Mr and Miss Morrison, Mr*. Binger, Mrs W T. Smith. Those responsible for decorating the church were Mesdamrs Eyre, Roberts, and Algernon Ward, Misses Barwell, Dodd, Morrison, and Talbot, and Mr Heaton.
The collections throughout the day were for the fond for the poor and amounted to P.T. 2,133 5 10.

CORPORATION OF WESTERN
EGYPT.

It has been brought to our notice that state­ments are being made to the effect that the recent series of article* which we published on the present state if the development of the concession of the Corporation of Western Egypt were directly or irdir'ctly inspired by the company. Tbi* allegation is quite ui true. The articles were the outcome of a trip to the Great Oasis made by the writer, the editor of thi* newspaper, on hia own initiative, and not a single one of the artiolei were revised by or subtfiitted to anyone interested in the company prior to their publication in the 'Egyptian Gszette.” Our object was merely to set before the Egyptian public a straightforward, matter of fact statement of the beginnings of what is really the moat important land development scheme that has ever been attempted in modern Egypt

“CARMEN."
(From our Thxatrical Cdrrupundbnt.)

1 came in rather late in the 2nd act, after hearing the singing at Sbepheard's and I wish ed I had s'ayed at Shenheard's. “Carmen" was really just about as bad as it could be. The only relieviag feature* were Ml'e Devilloy and M Fontaine. M. Fontaine, for once, seemed to have freed his voice: it was clear and resonant, and without effort in the lower register. Id fact, all his usual faults were, for onee, absent. Mlle Devilloy was delightful, co sweet and true, and with such a charm in every note, that she was encored, and we all wished Mioae'a were a big part instead of being only secondary M&ry as E*oamillo seemed to me very apathetic , I was told the Toreador song was not by any mean* wonder fol. Mme Chaix Bonheur, of whom 1 had heard so much, was most disappointing, and far too melodramatic; her voice wasn't pleasing at all: it was too coarse and masculine, as was indeed the whole of her interpretation. The rest of the singers and the orcheatra were al! at sixes and leven*. quite tuneless, out of time, often actually singing false. The orchestra was just possible when by itself, but the moment any singing began everything went wrong. I quite agree with “ L'Egypte'a ” proposal to change them radically and entirely They evidently have no spontaneity or responsivene**, and they play badly, and no amount of bard work will improve them The result is that only the fdw good singers oan do anything, and that by forcing them selves and rest on to the right note, or oom promising on the wrong note. The others and 'he chorus have no chance against such discordant apathy
“LA BOH EMR"

To one who bad seen “Carmen' at Cairo last Monday night, any performance of any opera might well have aeemed excellent. Buch was our case ; but even after discounting this artificial autbesissm ore must admit that there were roally few faults in last night's “Bohfcme ;” there were email, but annoying. In the first place, the one performer whose voice should never be beard at all, the con­ductor, to wit, talked much too loud and much too long , over tbs roller an.I in the noisier passages h s rounded tones were au dible throughout the house, now challeng­ing his orches'ra to further effort*, now al laying their superfluous z*al. When the prompter sl*o gave tongue, deep answering to deep, our last particle ot dramatu illusion wm lost. Then the horrible encore bsbit reasserted I'self. FOREIGN Trade
The estimated figure* of the exports and imports of meroh ui'li** and «pecis for the year 1906 are shown below together with the totals for the last six years, as given by the Customs Returns

The large increase in the exports for 1906 is, of course, lae to the abundant cotton crop and the high pricas ruling The upward move moot in the import* is b*rdly leas remarkable, raising their value as it does to a figure which ;* some 10 °; higher than that of 19o5 This notable progress appears by the customs returns to be shared by nearly all classes nt the import trade, the most prominent advance being in the category of me'ahand machinery, which alone acooont* for 40 £ of the total increase

In my Note last year I said "The fact that during the peat two years the imports of mer ohandise and specie taken together have greatly outbalanced the exports, notwithstanding the constant heavy charges for the servioe of the foreign debt, oonstitutee a phenomenon that calls for reflection. A readjustment in the direction of normal equilibrium must come sooner or later, and, if we are paying for our imports with capital provided by tbe foreign investor, the operation, though by no means unsound at present, cannot be indefluitely continued.1' These remarks were somewhat severely criticised by a portion of the local Press, which was inclined to accuse me of economic heresy and pessimistic fore bodings In tbe passage quoted above I was far from desiring to formulate any economic theory, beretioal or otherwise, but tbe fact that tbe total import* of merchandise and specie in 1900 amounted to L E 18,200,000 as against L.E. 21,600,000 for export*, leaving a balance of LE 3.400,(00 in favour of export a while in 1906 tbe figures are, imports LE. 31,900,000 and export* LE 2*.500 0 0, showing a balance of over LB. 3 400000 in favour of import*, i* a phenomenon worthy of attention and study Even if these figure* imply that Egypt has been paying for her import* with funds advanced by tbe foreign capitalist, there is nothing necessarily alarm ing in the fact, so long as tbe capital in qoes tion is employed fur tbe purpose of remenera tive enterprise

A special feature in tbe budget of last year wu the reduction of tbe import duty on certain articles of first necessity from 8 ' to 4 , ad valorem Unfortunately, the oondi tions which have prevailed during the past year ar* not such s« to furnish a fair basis on which to form a definite opinion as to the precise effect of this reduction In tbe first place, there were considerable accumulations of stocks to be disposed of before tbe consumers could expect to benefit by tbe reduction, and secondly, foreign market prices and freigb’e for most of tbe articles were higher tbia year

Moreover, tbe state of tbj local market fur cattle and petroleum was abnormal, owing to quarantine restriotions, and to the temporary atoppage of arrivals of petroleum during the disturbances in Rneeia.

Judging, however, from the data before me. I am ino'ined to think that, having regard to tbe recent rapid advance of prosperity, a ledoo tion ol 4% on article* of first necessity w 1! not be found, for the moment, to have affected the consumption to any very great ex'enl, whatever the final re.nits may be If this view proves to be correct, it may, at all event*, be claimed for the measure taken last year that, while it benefits the consumers, it also furnishes tbe Government with a fiaoal reserve which conld be made use of in oase of emergency with the least pose ble disturbing effect upon trade

Gold Demand of tub Egyptian M*ukt
It may *ot be out of place here to offer •ome remarks on recent import* uf specie to Egypt which have attracted some attention in the financial world.

Gold ooiu is invariably mposted in conn derabls quantity in tbe autumn in order to move the oollen wop, th* amount required depending oa the value of the orop (quantity X price), the rapidity with wbii b it u brought to market, aad the reserve* aiseady ssistieg in the imnds uf ib* banks Tbe first of these is usually tbe predownnaUng iaoter. Io the proses t instance, th* e* •aptional y large volume of th* erop and tbe hi|k pnoes it commanded enupioi with th* tact that the cultivators took tbe opportunity of selling their cotton earner than usual, brought itsAout tret the de*eand tsi gold mad* itself felt with great suddend**a at th* beginning of October. The reserve* in ths Banks were quickly exhausted, and a temporary financial stoingency ensued, which was ultimately alienated by the arrival of gold from Eusope

Tbe demand foigold in large quantities for Egypt, oonaUtutiag as it does a phenomenon of annual occurrence, would probably have passed without comment bad it not fallen, concentrated and sudden, upon a maike’ already short uf supplies. The withdrawal of •ome four million! from tbe London money market for Egypt during tbe mouth of October was doubtla s the principal o*um of tbs advance of the Bank of B iglaud rate to 6 % It may be observed her* that no ns* in the rate of interest will arrest a drain of gold to move the Egyptian cotton crop, for, owing to tbe reluctance of tba native cultivator to accept anything bat actual coin in payment of hi* cotton, a permanent cbeok to tbe snpplia* would stop the entire commerce of tbe oountry and lead to the moat serious oonseqoenoa-.

In view of the apprehension! which have found expression in some quarters, it is the more necessary to lay emphasis un the fset that ths recent demand for gold was a purely trade demand, aud was in no way connected with the financing of speculative operations. Although it is incontestable, a* I bad occasion to point out in my last Not*, that such opera tious hive been foatared to a ooasiderabl* ax'ent of reo*nt years with the help of foreign capital, they should not be confounded with tbe normal and legitimate commerce of the country. row.cell: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio Rubattino Co s steamers, which leave Alex andna wtstkly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMINA, one of the most charm ing ami [xipular places on the island (iiardint is the station at which to alight, and the drive ui» to Taormina is moet delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna, and here also is a fine Cathedral The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless source of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which w&t designed by Demosthenes in B.c 41.3, and taken by the Romans in n c 212, when Archimedes wa- slain his tomb is to lie seen The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300, (JOO inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a dehgthful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city The Palazw Kral* is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of .V z>va<reinia degh Erimiti with its picturesque cloisters The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit

'Phe fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio Ruliattino Co.’s steam ers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explure some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Cattdlamarr and ibrrMfo. The siyall steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Gapri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well known to need comment here

Ixiaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well l»e sjient admiring the City nf Elouerr and its surrounding country. In Florunue itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing inte rest, whilst the local promenades and excur­sions should not lie omitted. The (jaxine is the moat attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Eunqie, otiened 35 yw ago, goes winding up through the hills

row.cell: The only Hotel with Central Heating.

cell.p: i a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to I allam br<*a, with its Mvnantevy 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ell«r<>. thence by cog wheel railway to Saltina The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking i«noramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours , here there is a fine Cftthedial and the Leaning Tower A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Canqiauile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO One of the most delightful places <>n the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from R une to Genoa. It Is a very convenient half way house between Egypt ano England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally gms.1

The patriarchal home <f Italy’s most an cient nobility, whose palaces, gardena, ami famouH collection* of statuary, freacoex and ]>aintings, are a constant delight to thousands of ’reveller’ who annually sojourn in Genoa Then there are the superbly decorated medie val churches containing exquirite marble calumns and historical paintings, and the in comjiarahle (xuipc Santa filled with its won­derful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northernlta ly la'fore making the tonr of the lakes. The I’athedral is the principal attrai tioii, with its la'autifiil windows illustrating the History of the Bible 'Hie public gardens and the mono mental (emeb ry are also worth a visit

VENICE is a 5 hours jonrney by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay Th>* total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one a* very strange , no horse, cart, camage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn The approach the Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea |s>rt. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphnslite, bom of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of ruck, but first the tops of Cum |>anilex appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole ghtp-nng town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
( I'MO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in oueand a quarter hours by tram by way of Monza .

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a ehanning spot, then come Tremezza, Cadrnaldna, and Mrnaggto with the prettily situated town of Hellaggio opposite. The walk from 7’remeiso along the shore of the lake to Minaggio is most enjoyable A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezzei on lake Lugano in three quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two and 1 three quarter hours

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como, and reached by train in one-and a hall hours. It has a population of 10,000 iieople and is charm ingly situaUsl on the Ijake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M San Salvatore. M. de Caprino and M Generoeo.

LOCAKNtl may lie reached by rail from B*dlinzona in forty minutes This pretty town, situated at the top of l<ake Maggiore, has a mild climate, and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interest­ing paintings, “Entombment," by Ciseri, and "'1 he Flight into Egypt, by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A sinking picture on the La! e of Lucerne facing the Kigi and Pilatun and the snow-clad Alps
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by ls»at, rail, etc, are very numerous

The Eih of Lucerne abounds in delightful I excursions, those to the Kigi, Pilaf tu, Hurg. n »tock and .Sunnenfawy needing a special visit each Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever<hanging sitnery on the trip from Lucerne to Eluden is a source of delight to tlie lover of nature.

BRl’NNEN, charmingly situated on the most l>eautiful part of the I^ke of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the lavke of I’ri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous A jenirasee

Till N (on the Ixtke of Thun) half an hour from Berne and one hour from Interlaken. Quiet and quaint , sheltered from winds , just the place to rest and recnj»erate Beautiful walks, through w»l>, and along the lake shore. Kursaal, Concerts, Casino, flares, Tennis, Boating, etc
